author: TNN
title: Feels Like Winter, Finally: Fog Hits Rail Traffic, Pulls Down Max Temp | Ludhiana News - Times of India
text: Ludhiana: With the temperature dropping by nearly 6°C, dense fog enveloped Ludhiana on Thursday, bringing down visibility in the morning to 100 metres and impacting rail traffic too.The worse is yet to come, as the meteorological department has issued a red warning for Ludhiana for Friday and Saturday, predicting dense to very dense fog. A red warning is issued for the authorities concerned to take action in view of high predictability of adverse weather conditions. More trains are expected to get delayed in future too. Ludhiana railway station superintendent Amrik Singh said 10-12 trains were delayed because of poor visibility during the day, with the Jammu Rajdhani, which plies from New Delhi to Jammu Tawi, getting delayed by more than five hours.While visibility was poor for most of the morning, it improved to 350 metres by 11.30am. There was moderate fog for the remaining part of the day and sunlight could barely make it past the grey skies. Day temperature dropped to 12.8°C in the city, 5.9°C below normal and fall of 5.8°C from Wednesday.The minimum temperature, also called night temperature, was recorded at 10.3°C, which is 5°C above normal. As per the meteorological department, day temperature in the city might rise to 21°C by Sunday, whereas night temperature might fall to 9°C on Friday. It could further fall to 6°C by next week. Residents too had a difficult time because of poor visibility in the morning hours. Deepak Kumar, a resident, said he was driving on the Southern bypass that runs parallel to Sidhwan canal, but had to stay slow due to fog. Major trains which were delayed because of bad weather included Malwa Express, Amritsar Shatabdi and Shan-e-Punjab. We also published the following articles recentlyDense fog envelopes parts of North India, reduces visibilityThe winter chill continues to grip North India with dense fog in cities like Kanpur, Aligarh, Prayagraj, and Meerut in Uttar Pradesh, and Gwalior in Madhya Pradesh. Locals gathered around bonfires for warmth on the streets. The India Meteorological Department recorded visibility of 00m in Agra, Prayagraj, and Gwalior. In Delhi, the temperature dropped to 9.4 degrees Celsius with visibility as low as 125 meters. The air quality in Delhi remained 'very poor' with an AQI of around 400, leading to a ban on non-essential construction work in the Delhi-NCR region.106267801Dense fog engulfs Delhi-NCR; flights, trains delayedDelhi experiences dense fog with reduced visibility, causing delays for flights. Temperature drops to 7 degrees Celsius. Air Quality Index (AQI) remains in the \"very poor\" category at 374. Isolated pockets of Delhi and surrounding areas expected to have very dense fog. Air pollution continues to be a major concern.106281393IMD issues red warning for very dense fog todayThe weather department has issued a red warning for very dense fog in Delhi-NCR on Friday, urging people not to venture out in their vehicles between 4 am and 10 am. The warning aims to prevent car pile-ups and accidents caused by low visibility. The improvement in fog conditions on Thursday was due to overnight winds, but the wind speed is expected to drop on Friday, leading to very dense fog. The IMD has also issued an orange alert for dense to moderate fog on Saturday. The air quality in Delhi remains very poor, and the situation is not favorable for effective dispersion of pollutants.106362105
